links.title: International Obfuscated C Code Contest - Wikipedia
links.description: The International Obfuscated C Code Contest (abbreviated IOCCC) is a computer programming contest for the most creatively obfuscated C code. Held annually in the years 1984–1996, 1998, 2000, 2001, 2004–2006, 2011–2015 and then in 2018, it is described as "celebrating [C's] syntactical opaqueness".[1] The winning code for the 25th contest, held in 2018, was released in May 2018.[2]

links.title: INT 13H - Wikipedia
links.description: INT 13h is shorthand for BIOS interrupt call 13hex, the 20th interrupt vector in an x86-based computer system. The BIOS typically sets up a real mode interrupt handler at this vector that provides sector-based hard disk and floppy disk read and write services using cylinder-head-sector (CHS) addressing.

links.description: Maslow's hierarchy of needs is a theory in psychology proposed by Abraham Maslow in his 1943 paper "A Theory of Human Motivation" in Psychological Review.[2] Maslow subsequently extended the idea to include his observations of humans' innate curiosity. His theories parallel many other theories of human developmental psychology, some of which focus on describing the stages of growth in humans. links.title: FACOM 128A and 128B Relay Computers-Computer Museum
links.description:
The FACOM 128A, which was completed in 1956, was the first domestically produced relay-based business computer. Developed by Fuji Tsushinki Manufacturing Corporation (today, Fujitsu), the first machine was delivered to the Ministry of Educationâs Institute of Statistical Mathematics in September 1956. 
The 128A was based on experiences with the FACOM 100, but the circuit behavior and the calculation methods were redesigned from the ground up, ...

Study shows that the Moon is older than previously believed
links.description: A new study spearheaded by Earth scientists at the University of Cologne's Institute of Geology and Mineralogy has constrained the age of the Moon to approximately 50 million years after the formation of the solar system. After the formation of the solar system, 4.56 billion years ago, the Moon formed approximately 4.51 billion years ago. The new study has thus determined that the Moon is significantly older than previously believed—earlier resea...

links.title: Early Moon formation inferred from hafnium–tungsten systematics
links.description: The Moon formed around 50 Myr after the Solar System, suggests a lunar silicate Hf/W ratio higher than that of Earth, from high-precision compositional analysis of lunar rock samples.

links.title: Early formation of the Moon 4.51 billion years ago
links.description: Establishing the age of the Moon is critical to understanding solar system evolution and the formation of rocky planets, including Earth. However, despite its importance, the age of the Moon has never been accurately determined. We present uranium-lead dating of Apollo 14 zircon fragments that yield highly precise, concordant ages, demonstrating that they are robust against postcrystallization isotopic disturbances. Hafnium isotopic analyses of t...

links.description: The Late Heavy Bombardment (LHB), or lunar cataclysm, is a hypothesized event thought to have occurred approximately 4.1 to 3.8 billion years (Ga) ago,[1] at a time corresponding to the Neohadean and Eoarchean eras on Earth. During this interval, a disproportionately large number of asteroids are theorized to have collided with the early terrestrial planets in the inner Solar System, including Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars.[2] Since 2018, the e...

links.title: Trovafloxacin - Wikipedia
links.description: Trovafloxacin (sold as Trovan by Pfizer and Turvel by Laboratorios Almirall) is a broad spectrum antibiotic that inhibits the uncoiling of supercoiled DNA in various bacteria by blocking the activity of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.[1] It was withdrawn from the market due to the risk of hepatotoxicity. It had better Gram-positive bacterial coverage and less Gram-negative coverage than the previous fluoroquinolones.

links.title: STOBAR - Wikipedia
links.description: STOBAR (Short Take-Off But Arrested Recovery), a system used for the launch and recovery of aircraft from the deck of an aircraft carrier, combines elements of short take-off and vertical landing (STOVL) with catapult-assisted take-off but arrested recovery (CATOBAR).

links.title: CATOBAR - Wikipedia
links.description: CATOBAR (Catapult Assisted Take-Off But Arrested Recovery or Catapult Assisted Take-Off Barrier Arrested Recovery) is a system used for the launch and recovery of aircraft from the deck of an aircraft carrier. Under this technique, aircraft launch using a catapult-assisted take-off and land on the ship (the recovery phase) using arrestor wires.

links.title: Demystifying Venture Capital Economics - Wealthfront Knowledge Center
links.description: Much has been written about the performance of companies backed by venture capital; little has been written on the economics of the VC industry itself.

links.title: Demystifying Venture Capital Economics, Part 2 - Wealthfront ...
links.description: Just because a company operates at a loss today doesn’t mean it can’t be profitable in the future. Those unfamiliar with venture capital economics struggle with this notion.

links.title: Demystifying Venture Capital Economics, Part 3 - Wealthfront ...
links.description: The venture capital invested in market winners is almost always justified, which benefits premier venture VC firms and consistently hurts the second tier.

links.title: Software Companies Should Be Judged On Their Rate Of Innovation
links.description: Not all automated investment services innovate at the same rate. Significant differences in the rate of product improvement can impact consumers greatly.

links.title: How Do You Recognize a Sinking Ship? - Wealthfront Knowledge Center
links.description: You need to understand how to spot the signs your company might soon fail, in other words how to recognize a sinking ship in time to find a new job.

links.title: Demystifying Venture Capital Economics - Innovation
links.description: Industry observers consistently make the same mistake. They evaluate innovations based on their magnitude of adoption, rather than their rate of adoption.

links.title: Demystifying Venture Capital Economics - Partnering with Incumbants
links.description: Almost startup eventually needs to decide if it should partner with a large company to accelerate growth. We discuss the right and wrong reasons to do so.

links.title: Steve Jobs – IPod Introduction

links.title: Compendium (software) - Wikipedia
links.description: Compendium is a computer program and social science tool that facilitates the mapping and management of ideas and arguments. The software provides a visual environment that allows people to structure and record collaboration as they discuss and work through "wicked problems".

links.title: Language in Thought and Action
links.description: The truism that we all mean the same things when we use the same words has unwanted consequences in politics, advertisement and life.

links.title: The Sahara buried this ancient Roman cityâpreserving it for centuries
links.description: Once a thriving North African military outpost, Thamugadi was forgotten under desert sands, until a Scottish explorer went looking for it centuries later.

links.title: The Story of the PING Program
links.description:
Yes, it's true!  I'm the author of
	ping for UNIX.
Ping is a little thousand-line hack that I wrote in an evening which
practically everyone seems to know about. :-)


I named it after the sound that a
sonar makes, inspired by the whole principle of echo-location.
In college I'd done a lot of modeling of sonar and radar systems,
so the "Cyberspace" analogy seemed very apt.
It's exactly the same paradigm applied to a new problem domain:
ping uses...
links.original_title: The Story of the Ping Program (1997)

The Cuckoo's Egg - Wikipedia
links.description: The Cuckoo's Egg: Tracking a Spy Through the Maze of Computer Espionage is a 1989 book written by Clifford Stoll. It is his first-person account of the hunt for a computer hacker who broke into a computer at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL).

links.title: PiDP-11 | Obsolescence Guaranteed
Indigenous Maize: Who Owns the Rights to Mexico’s ‘Wonder’ Plant?
links.description: A nitrogen-fixing maize grown in an indigenous region of Mexico has the ability to fertilize itself, recent research shows. Now, as a global company and U.S. scientists work to replicate this trait in other corn varieties, will the villages where the maize originated share fairly in the profits?
links.original_title: Indigenous Maize: Who Owns the Rights to Mexico’s ‘Wonder’ Plant?

links.title: Nitrogen-fixing corn is farming’s holy grail. But when?
links.description: Groundbreaking research could dramatically lower farmer costs and protect groundwater.
